title: Autism Spectrum Disorder In India: Study Highlights Urgent Need For Early Detection And Support - Zee News
summary:
Autism Spectrum Disorder In India: Study Highlights Urgent Need For Early Detection And Support

Publication Date: Friday, Source: The Lancet Psychiatry

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a significant health burden in India, according to a new study. The findings indicate the need for urgent support and early detection strategies for individuals affected by the disorder.

  • The study ranks autism among the top 10 causes of non-fatal health burden for youth under 20 in India.
  • In 2021, India recorded 708.1 cases of ASD per 100,000 persons, with a notable gender disparity.
  • Globally, 61.8 million people were reported as autistic, representing one in every 127 individuals.
  • The highest prevalence of ASD was found in high-income Asia Pacific countries, while Tropical Latin America and Bangladesh had the lowest.
  • Researchers urge prioritization of resources for early detection and improved diagnostic tools, especially in low and middle-income countries.
“The findings underscore the urgent need for early detection and sustained support for autistic individuals and their caregivers worldwide,”

The study calls for enhanced geographic data coverage and targeted interventions to address comorbidities and risks such as suicide in individuals with ASD.
newTitle: Study Highlights Urgent Need for Early Detection of Autism Spectrum Disorder in India

Hearing and vision loss linked to heart disease and stroke - The Week
summary:
Hearing and Vision Loss Linked to Increased Risk of Heart Disease and Stroke

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Journal of the American Heart Association

A recent study from China highlights that middle-aged and older adults with hearing and vision impairments face a greater risk of cardiovascular diseases, including strokes and heart attacks.

This study analyzed data from 11,332 Chinese adults aged 45 and older without a history of cardiovascular disease. Key findings include:

  • 2,156 participants experienced cardiovascular events over seven years.
  • Vision impairment alone increases risk by 24%.
  • Hearing impairment alone increases risk by 20%.
  • The risk escalates to 35% for those with both hearing and vision problems.
“With the continuous aging of the population, the incidence and prevalence of hearing loss and impaired vision are increasing.”

By 2050, it is projected that 895 million people will have visual impairments and 2.5 billion will suffer from hearing loss worldwide. Researchers advocate for the screening and treatment of sensory deficits to help reduce cardiovascular disease burdens.

This study emphasizes the importance of addressing sensory health to improve cardiovascular outcomes.
newTitle: Hearing and Vision Loss Linked to Increased Risk of Heart Disease and Stroke

title: Mixed study on barriers of access to prevention, diagnosis and treatment of gestational malaria in pregnant women at risk from an endemic region of Colombia - Malaria Journal
summary:
Barriers to Accessing Care for Pregnant Women with Gestational Malaria in Colombia

Published: 21 December 2024 | Source: Malaria Journal

Gestational malaria (GM) poses significant health risks to pregnant women in Colombia, yet research on barriers to access for prevention, diagnosis, and treatment has been sparse. This study analyzes these barriers among women in endemic regions of Colombia.

Key Points:

  • GM is linked to severe health complications for mothers and babies.
  • The study involved 400 pregnant women, identifying both quantitative and qualitative barriers to healthcare access.
  • Major barriers included delays in medical care and limited access to medications.
  • Half of the respondents reported multiple barriers, with significant variations among socioeconomic groups.
  • Findings emphasize the need for interventions targeted at improving healthcare access for vulnerable populations.
“It is important to expand the health action of GM control and to improve the care of pregnant women and their quality of life.”
newTitle: Barriers to Accessing Care for Pregnant Women with Gestational Malaria in Colombia

You think OCD is just about cleanliness? You got it wrong all this long - India Today
summary:
Understanding OCD Beyond Cleanliness: A Deeper Look

Published On: Dec 21, 2024
Source: India Today

This article explores the complex nature of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), dispelling myths that it only pertains to cleanliness and showcasing its serious implications on those affected.

  • OCD involves intrusive thoughts and repetitive behaviors, significantly affecting daily life.
  • Common misconceptions equate OCD with mere cleanliness obsessions.
  • The disorder can stem from genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors.
  • Effective management includes therapy, medication, and lifestyle changes.
“It is important to create an environment where individuals with OCD feel understood, supported, and empowered to seek help...” - Piyali Maity

The article emphasizes the importance of understanding OCD beyond stereotypes and supporting individuals facing this challenging disorder.
newTitle: Understanding OCD Beyond Cleanliness: A Deeper Look

title: Study finds a subset of artificial heart patients can regenerate heart muscle - News-Medical.Net
summary:
Study finds a subset of artificial heart patients can regenerate heart muscle

Publication Date: 2024 | Source: Circulation

A research team co-led by a physician-scientist at the University of Arizona discovered that some patients with artificial hearts possess the ability to regenerate heart muscle, which could pave the way for new treatments for heart failure.

  • Nearly 7 million U.S. adults are affected by heart failure, which contributes to 14% of annual deaths.
  • The research shows that patients with artificial hearts regenerate muscle cells at over six times the rate of healthy hearts.
  • Future research aims to understand why some patients respond to artificial heart treatment while others do not.
“Irrefutable evidence of heart muscle regeneration has never been shown before in humans,” said Hesham Sadek, MD, PhD, director of the Sarver Heart Center.

This study signifies a major milestone in understanding heart muscle regeneration potential, which could lead to better treatments for heart failure.
newTitle: Study finds a subset of artificial heart patients can regenerate heart muscle

title: Do you feel awfully cold? 5 reasons that may be causing it - The Times of India
summary:
Do You Feel Awfully Cold? 5 Reasons That May Be Causing It

Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

Feeling unexpectedly cold can be uncomfortable and concerning. This article explores five possible reasons behind such sensations, offering insights into how to address them.

  • Hypothyroidism can cause a persistent sense of coldness.
  • Poor circulation may result in cold extremities.
  • Chronic fatigue syndrome can amplify feelings of cold.
  • Anemia affects red blood cells and can lead to feeling chilly.
  • Raynaud's disease can cause episodes of reduced blood flow to extremities.
“Understanding the underlying causes is crucial for effective treatment.”

It's vital to consult a healthcare professional if persistent cold sensations occur, as they may indicate underlying health issues.
newTitle: Do You Feel Awfully Cold? 5 Reasons That May Be Causing It

Role of community & constant surveillance key to combat vector-borne diseases: Experts - Deccan Herald
summary:
Role of community & constant surveillance key to combat vector-borne diseases: Experts

Published: 20 December 2024, 21:32 IST

Bengaluru experts stress the importance of community involvement and ongoing pathogen monitoring in fighting vector-borne diseases, revealed during a panel discussion at the Visvesvaraya Industrial and Technological Museum.

  • Experts highlight the increased need for pathogen surveillance due to rising public health challenges.
  • Prof. Jayaraman Srinivasan warns of extreme heat-related deaths in coastal cities if interventions aren't implemented.
  • Critique of policymakers who attribute health issues solely to climate change.
  • Mansi Malik emphasizes the need for advanced genome sequencing techniques in understanding virology.
  • Call for pathogen surveillance to adapt to changing societal and climatic conditions.
“Pathogen surveillance must adapt to the rapidly changing societal and climatic conditions to effectively tackle emerging health threats.” - Mansi Malik

Experts reaffirm that vigilant community action and efficient surveillance are critical in mitigating the risks posed by vector-borne diseases in the face of climate change.
newTitle: Experts Emphasize Community Action and Surveillance Against Vector-Borne Diseases

  • The study reveals that a specific gut virus may play a role in triggering Alzheimer's.
